PURPOSE OF STUDY AND SUMMARY OF FINDINGS

i

The Statewide Trails Study is an element of Maryland’s 1983 Recreation and
Open Space Plan. The primary purpose of the study is to identify existing trails
and make recommendations for improving trail opportunities. The study achieves
the following objectives: ‘

1) provides an inventory of trails and hostels

2) provides an overview of public and private trail pmgram§

3) assesses the need for additional trails by type anﬂ-geégiaphic region
4) identifies potential trail routes in the State and locations for new hostels
5) presents information on trail guides and information sources

6) recommends future actions to be taken by trail and hostei providers to
increase trail and hostel opportunities

The major findings of the study are as follows:

1) Maryland has 3,047 miles of trail (see definition), of which 89 percent
(2,722 miles) is available for public use. State agencies own or provide
30 percent (928 miles) of the total mileage, more than any other trail pro-
vider in Maryland. Federal agencies, local jurisdictions and quasi-public
organizations are also important trail providers. If multi-use trails are
counted more than once, there is actually a total of 4,254 miles of trail
available for trail activities. There are currently three hostels in Maryland,
strategically located to support trail activities.

2) Private trail groups and conservation organizations in Maryland are ac-
tively involved in trail development and maintenance, land acquisition,
trail education programs, publication and sales of maps and guidebooks,
‘organizing trips and outings, and providing hostels. .

3) There is currently a supply of trails to meet minimum needs for all ac-
tivities except off-road vehicle and snowmobile use. However, the trail
mileage is not evenly distributed across the State, resulting in trail deficits
in some regions. There is also a need for more loop trails suitable for
overnight or weekend backpacking trips. Comrared to nearby states,
Maryland has a deficiency of National Recreation Trails.

4) Planning organizations and trail groups have identified a number of poten-
tial trail routes in the State. These range from long-distance trails such
as the Potomac Heritage Trail to local bikeway systems. There is poten-
tial for expanding the existing hostel system by developing new hostels
along the C&0 Canal Towpath and East Coast Bicycle Trail.

5) Trail guidebooks, brochures and maps are available for the major trails
and trail areas in the State. However, there are some unmarked or
undesignated trails which are not described in the available literature.
Trail opportunities would be improved if information on lesser known trails
were available to citizens. ,

STATE TRAIL AND HOSTEL ACTIVITIES



Trails

At the State level, trails are developed and maintained by the Department
of Natural Resources and the Department of Transportation. In addition, the
Department of State Planning has responsibilities related to trail planning and
development.

The Department of State Planning conducted this Statewide Trails Study to
assess trail opportunities and needs. The Department also maintains an inven-
tory of trails in the State as an element of the Statewide Recreation Inventory
and prepares the Maryland Recreation and Open Space Plan, which establishes
policies related to trail development in the State and contains an analysis of
the suitability of the State’s land base for trail-oriented recreation.

State trail policy calls for a unified statewide trail system that includes all
types of trails. Specific strategy recommendations include utilization of aban-
doned railroad rights-of-way, designation of selected public lands for off-road
vehicle use, designing specific trails for specific uses, development of more trails
on public lands and links between existing trails, and development of water trails.
In addition, the planning objectives in the State Action Programs which relate
to trails are given high priority. These are: 1) provision of corridors for limited
recreation uses such as bicycling, hiking, and others which relate to streams,
shorelines, and unique resource areas; 2) establishment of an interconnecting
system of walking, hiking, and riding trails along the ocean beach, bays, estuaries,
rivers and streams, linking activity centers.

The Department of Natural Resources acquires and manages parks, forests,
natural areas, and wildlife management areas in the State. These areas provide
a variety of trail-related recreation opportunities to the public. The Maryland Forest
and Park Service manages many of the State-owned trails and trail areas. State
parks contain a variety of trails, including hiking, biking, equestrian, nature,
and cross-country ski trails. State Natural Environmental Areas protect signifi-
cant natural resources and provide low intensity recreation opportunities. Some
of these have trails; others have potential areas for trail development.

State forests are under multiple-use management and provide opportunities
for low density dispersed recreation. Hiking, backpacking and cross-country skiing
are important trail-related activities in State forests. State forests also provide
trails for off-road vehicle users and snowmobilers.

State Wildlife Management Areas are managed by the Wildlife Administra-
tion primarily to protect and manage wildlife populations. Some trail activities
are permitted in these areas. Trail types and policies vary from area to area.
Most areas have either trails for foot travel, unpaved roads which are closed
to vehicles during certain seasons, wood roads which can accommodate foot
travel, or a combination of these corridors. Some areas allow horsebacking riding.

Natural Resource Management Areas are lands acquired by the State for a
variety of potential natural resource uses. Interim recreational uses are allowed
~ which do not conflict with the protection of natural resources. Currently, one of
these areas, Monocacy, contains trails. Other units should be considered as
potential areas for new trails.

State use of Program Open Space funds to acquire the Appalachian Trail cor-
ridor on South Mountain has resulted in State protection of about 80 percent
of the Trail in Maryland. Trail management responsibilities are shared by the
National Park Service (NPS), the Department of Natural Resources (DNR), and
the Potomac Appalachian Trail Club (PATC). A cooperative agreement between
DNR and PATC (1981) commits PATC to development and maintenance of the
trail in Maryland. Overall management policies presented in the Comprehen-
sive Management Plan developed by the National Park Service stress the im-
portance of an unregimented recreational experience in a natural setting and
encourage self-reliance by trail users.

Program Open Space funds are also alloted by DNR to local jurisdictions
for park acquisition and development. Trails have been developed in county and
local parks with these funds.

The State Highway Administration, Department of Transportation, is respon-
sible for bicycle-related planning and development for the State highway system,
coordination with local and county bicycle facility development programs, and
the coordination of intermodal aspects of bicycle transportation. The Highway
Administration has constructed a number of bikeways, replaced storm drain grates
to improve bicycle safety, and is providing for bicycle use on the State highway
system via smooth surfaced highway shoulders, wide curb lanes, and other im-
provements. Bicycle lockers at selected intermodal transfer points, a special bicy-
cle information telephone line, and a bicycle coordinator position for program
continuity are also included in agency’s efforts.

State Hostel Program

Three Hostels already exist in the State. Recommendations related to hostel
gevelowent in the State are contained in the Maryland Recreation and Open
pace Plan.

State hostel recommendations encourage the completion of a network of
privately developed and maintained hostels. This could be achieved by developing
a series of hostels around the Chesapeake Bay and along the Potomac River,
and by developing several hostels in Western Maryland, the general area north
of Baltimore and Washington, and in major cultural areas such as Annapolis and
Baltimore. New hostels should tie in with existing trail systems and with hostel
networks in adjoining states.

TRAILS IN MARYLAND

For purposes of this study, a trail is a route, path, road, corridor, or right-of-
way used for recreation, education, or transportation. Although a road is usu-
ally considered to be different than a trail, a road can serve as a trail in certain
situations; for example, bicycle touring routes and historical trails both utilize
roads.

Trail Types and Definitions
The Department has identified twelve trail types, defined as follows:

« Biking trails are signed facilities constructed within separate rights-of-way or
highway rights-of-way to encourage bicycle activity, develop bicyclist skills and
provide a recreation experience to the user. Because recreational bicycling also
takes place to some extent on roads which have been improved for bicycle com-
muter use, and on unsigned touring routes in scenic areas, these routes are
also listed on the trail charts and shown on the trail map. However, it should
be recognized that the purpose of many of the bicycle-related highway im-
provements made by the State and local governments is to meet the transporta-
tion needs of commuter cyclists. The unsigned touring routes listed in the charts
are “trails” in the sense that they follow clearly defined routes through scenic
areas of the State and are promoted as recreational and educational trails by
public and private groups. See Trail and Hostel Information Section for further
information on other unsigned touring routes identified by maps, atlases or
guidebooks.

e Cross-Country Ski trails include both trails designated for this activity and other
trails which are available and suitable for this activity.

e Equestrian trails include both trails designed or designated primarily for
horseback riding and other trails which are available and suitable for this activity.

« Fitness trails include parcours or exercise trails, and jogging paths.

Handicapped trails are trails designed for persons with physical or visual
disabilities.

Hiking trails include trails for day hiking and for backpacking.

« Historical trails follow historic routes, go through historic districts, and con-
nect historic sites. They often use existing roads or sidewalks; interpretive in-
formation is contained in a guidebook or brochure.

o Multi-Purpose trails are trails which accommodate a variety of non-motorized
uses. This category includes trails which do not fit a specific activity category.

e Nature trails include both interpretive trails, and short trails designed primarily
for nature observation.

Off-Road Vehicle trails are designated specifically for off-road vehicle use.
e Snowmobile trails are designated specifically for snowmobile use.

o Water trails are water routes designated as public water trails by organiza-
tions in the State. The existing water trails are intended primarily for canoe use.
There are numerous river and stream segments in the State which are navigable
by canoe or kayak but not specifically identified as trails. See Trail and Hostel
Information Section for further information.

Many trails accommodate several activities; for example, hiking trails are
often used for horseback riding and cross-country skiing. See the inventory charts
for activity information.

Although few trails are designed specifically for disabled persons, numerous
trails are accessible to persons with disabilities. Contact the trail information
sources listed in this study for further information.

Existing Trails

The Department has developed a trail classification system which
distinguishes between trails on the basis of length, circularity, and users at-
tracted. A complete State trail system should provide opportunities for trips of
varying time and distance. :

Long-distance trails are linear trails which are suitable for extended journeys
within the State or across other states; for example, the Appalachian Trail. These
trails attract persons from all over the State, local users, and persons from other
states.

Major loop trails are those which provide circuits of over five miles for either
day or overnight use; for example, the Elk Ridge - Applachian Trail circuit. Loop
trails eliminate the need for backtracking or car shuttles. They are well-suited
for weekend outings and are used by persons from most parts of the State.

Network trails are systems of short trails in specific areas which may or may
not connect. In many areas, network trails provide opportunities for circuits of
varying lengths, and can be explored from a base such as a public campground.
Savage River State Forest is an example of an area with network trails. These
trails are used by persons from most parts of the State, and by persons from
other states attracted to the area by related facilities such as campgrounds.

Local trails are those which do not form part of a major loop, network, or
long-distance system. A short nature trail or fitness path would be an example
of local trail. These trails are mainly used by residents of the immediate area.

Maryland currently has 3,047 miles of trail; 89 percent of this is available for
public use. The State owns 30 percent of the total mileage, regional agen-
cies and county and municipal jurisdictions have 27 percent of the total, quasi-
public organizations have 20 percent of the total, federal agencies have 11 per-
cent, private concerns have 11 percent, and the military has 1 percent. The trail
map only shows those trails and trail areas which are available for public use.
Many trails on public lands are partially or fully maintained by trail clubs and
conservation groups.

A summation of trail miles available for each activity (counting multi-use trails
more than once) shows that Maryland has 4,254 miles of trail. Hiking tops the
list with 1,463 miles, followed by biking with 981, equestrian with 832, historical
with 300, cross-country ski with 257, snowmobile with 103, water trails with
108, off-road vehicle with 78, nature with 80, multi-purpose with 29, fitness with
22, and handicapped with 1. See the inventory charts for additional information
on trails for specific activities.

Prominent trails in the State include a 40-mile segment of the Appalachian
Trail, a 16-mile segment of the Tuscarora - Big Blue Trail, the major portion (181
miles) of the C&0 Canal Towpath, 231 miles of the East Coast Bicycle Trail, the
20-mile Catoctin Trail from Gambrill State Park to Catoctin Mt. Park, the
Green Ridge Hiking Trail in Green Ridge State Forest which joins with the C&0
Canal Towpath to form a 45-mile loop, and the 17-mile Big Savage Hiking Trail
in Savage River State Forest.

Support Facilities

Support facilities such as trail shelters, camping areas, campgrounds, trailhead
parking areas, information centers and signs facilitate recreational use of many
trails. Existing support facilities include a chain of 5 shelters along the Ap-
palachian Trail, a chain of hiker/biker campsites along the C&0 Canal Towpath,
campgrounds and camping areas in federal parks, state parks and other areas
with network trails, information centers in federal and State parks, and 3 youth
hostels in or near trail areas in the State. Availability of trailhead parking varies
according to trail area, and season. Access to the long-distance trails is generally
good.

At this time, there is no statewide system for signing and blazing trails. The
clubs which maintain the Appalachian Trail use a system of white blazes for the
main trail, blue blazes for side trails and signs at trail junctions and trailheads.
The League of Maryland Horsemen has developed a system of horseshoe mark-
ings for equestrian trails. The Maryland Park Service uses brown posts and col-
ored arrows, although not all of its trails are marked this way at present. The
National Park Service uses mileage markers (numbered posts) and occasional
signs alotl:gdthe C&0 Canal Towpath. Other agencies and jurisdictions use their
own methods.

Some of the trails in the State follow paths, wood roads and other corridors
which are not signed or marked in any way. Historical trails are described by
interpretive guides and brochures but are usually not marked by signs. Trail users
will find it necessary to familiarize themselves with different signing/blazing
systems and should not always expect to find trails signed or blazed.

Hostels in Maryland

American Youth Hostels, Inc. defines a hostel as “a low cost, supervised,
overnight accommodation for people traveling for health, education, and recrea-
tion.” Hostels can function as valuable support facilities for major trails or trail
areas if conveniently located. Maryland currently has 3 hostels operated by
American Youth Hostels, Inc. located in Knoxville, Cambridge and Baltimore.
The hostel in Knoxville is strategically located by the Appalachian Trail and the
C&0 Towpath. The hostel in Cambridge ties in with bicycle trails and touring
routes on the Eastern Shore. The hostel in Baltimore opened in July, 1983, and
is close to historic sites and cultural attractions in the City.

have been used for trail development in selected parks. However, the program
will expire in 1990 unless Congress extends it. -

The following diseussion of trail use and needs identifies trail needs on a
m?ional and statewide basis. Demand analysis is based on the 1982 Statewide
Leisure Survey and trail inventory data collected during 1981-85.

Bicyeling

The State currently has 292 miles of bikeways independent of roads and 392
miles of touring routes identified as major trails by trail groups and planners;
these are the facilities best suited for recreational cycling. There are also 295
miles of bikeways on roads or road shoulders which accommodate both com-
muter cycling and recreational cycling. The 1982 Statewide Leisure Survey found
that 15 percent of the State’s population participated in bicycle trips (as :tmposed
to short rides around the neighborhood). Demand methodology shows that be-
tween 215 and 388 total miles of bicycle trails are needed to meet existing de-
mand. Because of changes in age in the population, the total mileage needed
to meet 1990 demand is slightly less, between 212 and 383 miles. Thus, the
current statewide supply is adequate.

Analysis on a regional basis shows that there is generally an adequate supply
of bicycle trails and routes in most regions of the State. The overall system could
be improved by developing more trails and touring routes in the rural and scenic
regions of the State such as the Frederick, Southern Maryland, and Upper
Eastern Shore regions. These regions combined only have 15 percent of the total
statewide mileage. There is also a deficit in the Baltimore Region.

The State Highway Administration points out that bicycle use, particularly

for beginners, is often restricted by barriers such as road design and auto traffic
volume. To encourage recreational bicycling, more bikeways are needed which
are separated from roads. Abandoned railroad rights-of-way are especially well-
suited as locations for bikeway development. i

Hiking

There are currently 1,463 miles of trails available for hiking. Twenty-seven
percent of the State’s population participates in hiking. Between 1,176 and 2,117
total miles of hiking trails are needed by 1990. While there is a supply of hiking
trails statewide to meet minimum needs, additional hiking trails are needed to
meet peak hiking demand. In addition, analysis by hic region shows
that there are large deficits in both the Baltimore and Suburban Washington
mgi(;ns. Western Maryland, with over 30 percent of the total mileage, has a large
surplus.

Fitness Activities

Maryland currently has 22 miles of fitness trails and 1,463 miles of trails
available for hiking. Forty-seven percent of the State’s population participates
in jogging or walking for pleasure (data from 1978 Statewide Leisure Survey).
A total of 1,360 miles are needed to meet existing demand; 1,450 total miles

are needed by 1990. There would appear to be a slight statewide deficit of trails

for fitness activities. However, many persons who jog or walk for pleasure utilize
sidewalks and road shoulders close to home. With the exception of parcours
exercise trails, there is limited need to provide additional trails specifically for
fitness activities.

Nature Walks

The State currently has 80 miles of trails designed primarily for nature walks.
In addition, many of the trails available for hiking (1,463 miles) are also suitable
for nature walks. Twenty-nine percent of the State’s population participates in
nature walks. Between 680 and 1,224 total miles of nature trails are needed to
meet existing demand. The 1990 demand is even higher, between 757 and 1,362
total miles. There does not appear to be a deficit of nature trails statewide;
however, marking of existing trails and provision of nature trails within large
scale recreation areas such as State Parks would provide useful additions for
nature trail activities. The Frederick and Lower Eastern Shore regions have
relatively few designated nature trails compared to the other regions in the State.

LOCAL AND REGIONAL TRAIL ACTIVITIES

At the local level, a number of counties have undertaken trail planning or
completed trail plans. Also, many of the Local Recreation Plans prepared by
the counties and Baltimore City during 1981-82 discuss trails. In general, the
counties most concerned with trails are the heavily populated counties near
Baltimore and Washington, and the mountainous, rural counties of Western
Maryland, which have many of the best trail areas in the State. Several
municipalities have developed trails and/or trail plans. In addition, two regional
plannirf\fg agencies and a regional tourism council have undertaken trail plan-
ning efforts.

Off-Road Vehicles

There are currently 78 miles of trails available for off-road vehicles and 103
miles available for snowmobiling. Six percent of the State’s population uses off-
road vehicles for recreational purposes. Between 523 and 785 total miles of off-
road vehicle trails are needed to meet existing demand. Between 425 and 637
total miles are needed by 1990. There is a large deficit of off-road vehicle trails
statewide. All the regions in the State except for Western Maryland show large
deficits for off-road vehicle trails. The supply in Western Maryland is adequate
to meet regional needs, however, the supply is not adequate to accommodate
the needed demand of persons from other regions of the State and from outside
the State. The Maryland Forest and Park Service and Garrett County planners
recommend an expanded system, particularly-for snowmobiles, to reduce over-
crowding. Most of the existing trails are too short and fragmented to provide
a high quality experience.

There are a number of private organizations and clubs in Maryland which

Trail Locational Criteria

Development of future trails should be guided by previously stated planning
objectives in the State’s Recreation and Open Space Plan, the analysis of statewide
and regional trail surpluses and deficits contained in this study, identification
of trail needs in the Local Recreation Plans prepared by the counties, and iden-
tification of trail needs by trail groups across the State.

Currently, there is an adequate supply of trails in the State to meet minimum
needs for all activities except off-road vehicle and snowmobile use. However,
the distribution of the nonmotorized trail mileage is unbalanced, resulting in
trail deficits for some activities in certain regions of the State. The largest deficits
are for hiking trails in the Baltimore and Suburban Washington regions. There

Maryland is the only region with a supply to meet minimum needs.

Existing corridors such as abandoned rail lines, utility rights-of-way, stream

be continued. The continued publication by trail interest groups of information

also assist in the provision of future opportunities.

Proposed Trails

distance trails would be enhanced by completing the Potomac Heritage Trail
in Maryland. This would involve developing a trail or bicycle route from Point
Lookout to the C&0 Canal terminus in Washington and a trail or bicycle route
from Cumberland to Youghiogheny River Lake. Prince George’s County has already

i

The Statewide Trails Study is an element of Maryland’s 1983 Recreation and
Open Space Plan. The primary purpose of the study is to identify existing trails
and make recommendations for improving trail opportunities. The study achieves
the following objectives: ‘

1) provides an inventory of trails and hostels

2) provides an overview of public and private trail pmgram§

3) assesses the need for additional trails by type anﬂ-geégiaphic region
4) identifies potential trail routes in the State and locations for new hostels
5) presents information on trail guides and information sources

6) recommends future actions to be taken by trail and hostei providers to

The major findings of the study are as follows:

1) Maryland has 3,047 miles of trail (see definition), of which 89 percent
(2,722 miles) is available for public use. State agencies own or provide
30 percent (928 miles) of the total mileage, more than any other trail pro-
vider in Maryland. Federal agencies, local jurisdictions and quasi-public
organizations are also important trail providers. If multi-use trails are
counted more than once, there is actually a total of 4,254 miles of trail
available for trail activities. There are currently three hostels in Maryland,
strategically located to support trail activities.

2) Private trail groups and conservation organizations in Maryland are ac-
tively involved in trail development and maintenance, land acquisition,
trail education programs, publication and sales of maps and guidebooks,
‘organizing trips and outings, and providing hostels. .

3) There is currently a supply of trails to meet minimum needs for all ac-
tivities except off-road vehicle and snowmobile use. However, the trail
mileage is not evenly distributed across the State, resulting in trail deficits
in some regions. There is also a need for more loop trails suitable for
overnight or weekend backpacking trips. Comrared to nearby states,
Maryland has a deficiency of National Recreation Trails.

4) Planning organizations and trail groups have identified a number of poten-

Trails

At the State level, trails are developed and maintained by the Department
of Natural Resources and the Department of Transportation. In addition, the
Department of State Planning has responsibilities related to trail planning and
development.

The Department of State Planning conducted this Statewide Trails Study to
assess trail opportunities and needs. The Department also maintains an inven-
tory of trails in the State as an element of the Statewide Recreation Inventory
and prepares the Maryland Recreation and Open Space Plan, which establishes
policies related to trail development in the State and contains an analysis of
the suitability of the State’s land base for trail-oriented recreation.

State trail policy calls for a unified statewide trail system that includes all
types of trails. Specific strategy recommendations include utilization of aban-
doned railroad rights-of-way, designation of selected public lands for off-road
vehicle use, designing specific trails for specific uses, development of more trails
on public lands and links between existing trails, and development of water trails.
In addition, the planning objectives in the State Action Programs which relate
to trails are given high priority. These are: 1) provision of corridors for limited
recreation uses such as bicycling, hiking, and others which relate to streams,
shorelines, and unique resource areas; 2) establishment of an interconnecting
system of walking, hiking, and riding trails along the ocean beach, bays, estuaries,
rivers and streams, linking activity centers.

The Department of Natural Resources acquires and manages parks, forests,
natural areas, and wildlife management areas in the State. These areas provide
a variety of trail-related recreation opportunities to the public. The Maryland Forest
and Park Service manages many of the State-owned trails and trail areas. State
parks contain a variety of trails, including hiking, biking, equestrian, nature,
and cross-country ski trails. State Natural Environmental Areas protect signifi-
cant natural resources and provide low intensity recreation opportunities. Some
of these have trails; others have potential areas for trail development.

State forests are under multiple-use management and provide opportunities
for low density dispersed recreation. Hiking, backpacking and cross-country skiing
are important trail-related activities in State forests. State forests also provide
trails for off-road vehicle users and snowmobilers.

State Wildlife Management Areas are managed by the Wildlife Administra-
tion primarily to protect and manage wildlife populations. Some trail activities
are permitted in these areas. Trail types and policies vary from area to area.
Most areas have either trails for foot travel, unpaved roads which are closed
to vehicles during certain seasons, wood roads which can accommodate foot
travel, or a combination of these corridors. Some areas allow horsebacking riding.

Natural Resource Management Areas are lands acquired by the State for a
variety of potential natural resource uses. Interim recreational uses are allowed
~ which do not conflict with the protection of natural resources. Currently, one of
these areas, Monocacy, contains trails. Other units should be considered as
potential areas for new trails.

State use of Program Open Space funds to acquire the Appalachian Trail cor-
ridor on South Mountain has resulted in State protection of about 80 percent
of the Trail in Maryland. Trail management responsibilities are shared by the
National Park Service (NPS), the Department of Natural Resources (DNR), and
the Potomac Appalachian Trail Club (PATC). A cooperative agreement between
DNR and PATC (1981) commits PATC to development and maintenance of the
trail in Maryland. Overall management policies presented in the Comprehen-
sive Management Plan developed by the National Park Service stress the im-
portance of an unregimented recreational experience in a natural setting and
encourage self-reliance by trail users.

Program Open Space funds are also alloted by DNR to local jurisdictions
for park acquisition and development. Trails have been developed in county and
local parks with these funds.

The State Highway Administration, Department of Transportation, is respon-
sible for bicycle-related planning and development for the State highway system,
coordination with local and county bicycle facility development programs, and
the coordination of intermodal aspects of bicycle transportation. The Highway
Administration has constructed a number of bikeways, replaced storm drain grates
to improve bicycle safety, and is providing for bicycle use on the State highway
system via smooth surfaced highway shoulders, wide curb lanes, and other im-
provements. Bicycle lockers at selected intermodal transfer points, a special bicy-
cle information telephone line, and a bicycle coordinator position for program
continuity are also included in agency’s efforts.

ally considered to be different than a trail, a road can serve as a trail in certain
situations; for example, bicycle touring routes and historical trails both utilize
roads.

Major loop trails are those which provide circuits of over five miles for either
day or overnight use; for example, the Elk Ridge - Applachian Trail circuit. Loop
trails eliminate the need for backtracking or car shuttles. They are well-suited
for weekend outings and are used by persons from most parts of the State.

Network trails are systems of short trails in specific areas which may or may
not connect. In many areas, network trails provide opportunities for circuits of
varying lengths, and can be explored from a base such as a public campground.
Savage River State Forest is an example of an area with network trails. These
trails are used by persons from most parts of the State, and by persons from
other states attracted to the area by related facilities such as campgrounds.

Local trails are those which do not form part of a major loop, network, or
long-distance system. A short nature trail or fitness path would be an example
of local trail. These trails are mainly used by residents of the immediate area.

Support Facilities

Support facilities such as trail shelters, camping areas, campgrounds, trailhead
parking areas, information centers and signs facilitate recreational use of many
trails. Existing support facilities include a chain of 5 shelters along the Ap-
palachian Trail, a chain of hiker/biker campsites along the C&0 Canal Towpath,
campgrounds and camping areas in federal parks, state parks and other areas
with network trails, information centers in federal and State parks, and 3 youth
hostels in or near trail areas in the State. Availability of trailhead parking varies
according to trail area, and season. Access to the long-distance trails is generally
good.

At this time, there is no statewide system for signing and blazing trails. The
clubs which maintain the Appalachian Trail use a system of white blazes for the

The League of Maryland Horsemen has developed a system of horseshoe mark-
ings for equestrian trails. The Maryland Park Service uses brown posts and col-
ored arrows, although not all of its trails are marked this way at present. The
National Park Service uses mileage markers (numbered posts) and occasional
signs alotl:gdthe C&0 Canal Towpath. Other agencies and jurisdictions use their
own methods.

Some of the trails in the State follow paths, wood roads and other corridors
which are not signed or marked in any way. Historical trails are described by
interpretive guides and brochures but are usually not marked by signs. Trail users
will find it necessary to familiarize themselves with different signing/blazing
systems and should not always expect to find trails signed or blazed.

Bicyeling

The State currently has 292 miles of bikeways independent of roads and 392
miles of touring routes identified as major trails by trail groups and planners;
these are the facilities best suited for recreational cycling. There are also 295
miles of bikeways on roads or road shoulders which accommodate both com-
muter cycling and recreational cycling. The 1982 Statewide Leisure Survey found

to short rides around the neighborhood). Demand methodology shows that be-
tween 215 and 388 total miles of bicycle trails are needed to meet existing de-
mand. Because of changes in age in the population, the total mileage needed
to meet 1990 demand is slightly less, between 212 and 383 miles. Thus, the
current statewide supply is adequate.

Analysis on a regional basis shows that there is generally an adequate supply
of bicycle trails and routes in most regions of the State. The overall system could
be improved by developing more trails and touring routes in the rural and scenic
regions of the State such as the Frederick, Southern Maryland, and Upper
Eastern Shore regions. These regions combined only have 15 percent of the total
statewide mileage. There is also a deficit in the Baltimore Region.

The State Highway Administration points out that bicycle use, particularly

for beginners, is often restricted by barriers such as road design and auto traffic
volume. To encourage recreational bicycling, more bikeways are needed which
are separated from roads. Abandoned railroad rights-of-way are especially well-

American Youth Hostels (AYH), Inc. has identified the need for additional
hostels to complete a chain along the C&0 Canal. AYH has plans to open a new
hostel in Princess Anne, Somerset County, and would like to develop other new
hostels in Annapolis and the Lower Eastern Shore. The new hostel in Baltimore is
strategically located in one of the State’s major cultural centers.

The Potomac Appalachian Trail Club hopes to develop a hostel or overnight
facility for hikers in West Virginia or Virginia, near Harpers Ferry. This proposed
facility would support both the Appalachian Trail and the C&0 Canal in Maryland.

Support Facilities

In general, trail groups surveyed for this study did not indicate dissatisfac-
tion with existing support facilities such as camping areas, trailhead parking
areas, and signs. Garrett County found that cross-country skiers would like the
State or private sector to provide more cabins near cross-country ski trails to
serve as a base for outings. The Maryland Forest and Park Service indicated
that inadequate marking and lack of trail brochures and maps makes many of
the forest roads and trails in Western Maryland relatively unuseable for trail ac-
tivities. The Potomac Appalachian Trail Club perceives a need for informational
signs at trailheads along the Appalachian Trail to present information on trail
etiquette, magal uses, and samr considerations. The Club supported plans by
the National Park Service to build a walkway on the railroad bridge between
Harpers Ferry and the C&0 Canal. The walkway was completed in 1985.

The need for support facilities will obviously vary according to the type of
trail, type of use, and the environment the trail crosses. At a minimum, trails
which are independent of roads should have adequate blazing or marking, ade-
quate parking at trailheads and access points, and accompanying information
to be obtained from guidebooks or maps. Frequently used overnight areas should
have potable water and a latrine. Camping areas should be designated or in-
dicated as such in trail guides or maps.

Trail Locational Criteria

Development of future trails should be guided by previously stated planning
objectives in the State’s Recreation and Open Space Plan, the analysis of statewide
and regional trail surpluses and deficits contained in this study, identification
of trail needs in the Local Recreation Plans prepared by the counties, and iden-
tification of trail needs by trail groups across the State.

Currently, there is an adequate supply of trails in the State to meet minimum
needs for all activities except off-road vehicle and snowmobile use. However,
the distribution of the nonmotorized trail mileage is unbalanced, resulting in
trail deficits for some activities in certain regions of the State. The largest deficits
are for hiking trails in the Baltimore and Suburban Washington regions. There
is a statewide deficit of trails for off-road vehicles and snowmobiles; Westem
Maryland is the only region with a supply to meet minimum needs.

Existing corridors such as abandoned rail lines, utility rights-of-way, stream
valleys, wood roads, and waterways are potential locations for trail development.
Existing efforts to acquire or develop these corridors for public trail use should
be continued. The continued publication by trail interest groups of information
on unmarked or undesignated trails, bikes touring routes and waterways will
also assist in the provision of future opportunities.

Proposed Trails

There are a number of specific actions which should be undertaken to round
out and unify the existing network of trails in the State. The system of long-
distance trails would be enhanced by completing the Potomac Heritage Trail
in Maryland. This would involve developing a trail or bicycle route from Point
Lookout to the C&0 Canal terminus in Washington and a trail or bicycle route
from Cumberland to Youghiogheny River Lake. Prince George’s County has already
identified a route for the Potomac Heritage Trail in the County which utilizes
existing bikeways. This proposal could serve as a starting point for future plan-
ning efforts to complete this trail.

Development of other proposed trails in Maryland is important. These in-
clude plans by the Army Corps of Engineers for a trail system around the Maryland
portion of Youghiogheny River Lake, Potomac Appalachian Trail Club trails which
will link Catoctin Park with the Appalachian Trail, and Sugarloaf Mountain with
the C&0 Canal and Little Bennett Regional Park (Montgomery County), the utiliza-
tion of abandoned railroad lines and utility rights-of-way in the Baltimore area
as recommended by the Regional Planning Council, Anne Arundel County’s plans
to develop a 14-mile trail along the abandoned B&A Railroad line, and trail
development on the section of the abandoned North Central Railroad line in
Baltimore County from Monkton north to the Pennsylvania border. Many of the
counties and municipalities have developed trail or bikeway plans with proposals
for specific trails. Important additions to local trail systems are anticipated as a
result of these planning efforts.

The Coastal Resources Division of the Department of Natural Resources has
identified potential trail areas through the Bay Access Park Study. Most of the
potential areas would have to be acquired by the public sector before being used
for trail activities. The Study identified sixteen potential trail areas in six coun-
ties adjacent to the Chesapeake Bay.

The Maryland Forest and Park Service has long-range plans to expand the
trail system in Savage River State Forest and to locate a new trail along Backbone
Mountain in Potomac State Forest.

Maryland’s existing trail system is characterizied by isolated networks of trails
in recreation activity centers. Connector trails between these networks or to long-
distance trails would result in a more unified, accessible trail system. There
is also a shortage of loop trails suitable for overnight or weekend backpacking
trips. Development of additional loop trails with opportunities for primitive camp-
ing will ease some of the use pressures on popular trails such as the Appalachian
Trail. The new 45-mile loop trail in Green Ridge State Forest is a good example
of how existing trails can be linked to form a major loop trail.

Compared to nearby states, Maryland has a deficiency of National Recrea-
tion Trails. Trail providers should identify trails in or near urban areas which
meet the criteria for National Recreation Trail status. The State, in particular,
should assess existing trails on State lands near Baltimore, Washington, and
Frederick. National Recreation Trail status does not bring financial assistance,
but does publicize the trail and helps to promote the National Trails System.

Future Hostels

Development of future hostels should be guided by previously stated policies
contained in the Maryland Recreation and Open Space Plan.

At present, the proposed network is only partially complete. Additional hostels
are needed to tie in with existing long-distance trails such as the C&0 Canal.

Priority should be given to the development of additional hostels to com-
plete the chain along the C&0 Canal and to support the East Coast Bicycle Trail.
For the C&0 Canal, potential locations for new hostels are Seneca, Williamsport,
and Hancock. The 1976 General Plan for the Canal recommends hostels at 30-mile
intervals along the towpath.

The East Coast Bicycle Trail could be supported by one or more hostels. Hostels
along this trail should be located so as to be accessible to either Baltimore,
Annapolis, or the proposed Potomac Heritage Trail in Southern Maryland.

The Appalachian Trail has a chain of overnight shelters and campsites, and
passes the existing hostel at Knoxville. Trail groups feel that development of
an overnight facility in or near Harpers Ferry would benefit travelers on both
the Appalachian Trail and the C&0 Canal. The Tuscarora-Big Blue Trail would
benefit from a new hostel along the C&0 Canal Towpath in the vicinity of Han-
cock. Private organizations such as American Youth Hostels will continue to be
the key force behind hostel development in the State.

SUGGESTIONS FOR USERS



Bicyclists should use proper safety equipment, know how to ride in traffic,
and know the contents of the State’s Safety Handbook for Bicycle and Moped
Owners. Contact the Maryland Bicycle Information Telephone Line (659-1663)
for information and advice on these and other concerns. Hikers and backpackers
should be prepared to deal with insects, poisonous snakes, poison ivy, severe
weather conditions, and hostile dogs. Hikers may wish to avoid public hunting
areas during the hunting season. Suggestions for Appalachian Trail Users, publish-
ed by the Appalachian Trail Conference, has helpful information on equipment,
safety precautions and trip planning. Off-road vehicle users and snowmobilers
should know the State Rules and Regulations concerning off-road vehicles and
the areas on State lands designated for off-road vehicle use. Contact the Maryland
Department of Natural Resources for information. Canoeists should be properly
equipped and know the condition and characteristics of the waterway to be
traveled. Maryland boating regulations require personal flotation devices on all
boats. The Boating Handbook for Maryland Waters contains the State’s boating
regulations; contact the Department of Natural Resources. All trail users should
know emergency first aid techniques, the symptoms and treatment for hypother-
mia, and the safety precautions associated with each trail activity. If in doubt,
contact a trail group or the Red Cross.

Trail users should respect the rights of private property owners and refrain
from activities which could result in the loss of access privileges for the public
to trails on private lands.

Trail users should be aware that many trails and waterways in the State accom-
modate several activities and that conflicts between activities may occur. Uses
of a trail which are clearly illegal should be reported to the managing agency
or trail group responsible for the trail.

Litter has been a persistent problem on trails. Trail users should be prepared
to carry out everything they carry in and willing to clean up litter left by others.

Overnight users in undeveloped areas should practice low impact camping
techniques. Group size for overnight trips should be limited to 10 or less. Care
should be taken not to pollute water sources, damage vegetation or harm wildlife.

At present, there is no uniform statewide system for marking and signing
trails. Some trails are not marked or signed in any manner. Trail users will find
it necessary to familiarize themselves with a variety of blazing and signing
systems. Many trails are described and depicted in guidebooks and maps; trail
users will find these helpful in locating and following trails in the State. U.S.
Geological Survey topographic maps show contour lines, roads, streams, and
other features, and can be a useful tool in planning trail outings. See Trail and
Hostel Information for a list of resources.
